Naura Technology Group likely benefited from China’s $38 billion equipment investment as a top domestic tool supplier.
AMEC likely benefited from China’s $38 billion equipment investment due to its leading etch and CVD tools.
SiCarrier likely benefited from China’s $38 billion equipment investment as a Huawei-linked domestic toolmaker.
Yuliangsheng likely benefited from China’s $38 billion equipment investment by supplying immersion DUV lithography machines under trial at SMIC.
SMIC purchased chipmaking equipment as part of China’s $38 billion investment, trialing domestic DUV tools.
ASML was constrained from selling advanced lithography tools to China under U.S.-aligned export controls despite China’s $38 billion equipment investment.
Tokyo Electron was constrained from selling advanced semiconductor tools to China under Japanese export controls despite China’s $38 billion equipment investment.
Applied Materials was constrained from selling advanced semiconductor equipment to China under U.S. export controls despite China’s $38 billion equipment investment.

Beijing subsidised firms that purchase domestically produced GPUs for intelligent computing services under the April 2024 initiative

CXMT developed newer DRAM and NAND products despite export controls.
YMTC substituted U.S.-sourced equipment with domestic alternatives after restrictions.
YMTC expanded NAND flash memory development with capital injection from state funds.
Tongfu Microelectronics expanded advanced packaging capacity, including HBM and CoWoS-like processes.
